dimension: Approx. 9 blocks wide (x) × 9 blocks deep (z) × 1 block tall (y). From y=0 (ground) up to y=1.
position: Center it so x and z range roughly from -4 to +4 around (0, 0, 0). The top of this foundation lies at y=1.
tips: You may build the foundation solid if you want stability, or hollow it out to conserve blocks. Make sure it is level and covers the full 9×9 footprint to accommodate the walls.
description: A flat stone_bricks slab that serves as the house’s sturdy base, preventing direct contact with dirt or grass.

dimension: Continues the same 9×9 footprint. Built from y=1 up to y=4.
position: Place this layer on top of the foundation, forming walls around the edges. The finished top of these walls will be y=4.
tips: Leave room (1–2 blocks wide, 2 blocks high) for an entrance on one side if desired. Form any decorative arches or alcoves by adjusting the wall shape (e.g., adding recesses). Keep an interior space of about 7×7 inside.
description: Creates a robust, medieval-style first floor. Some sections might protrude or recess for detail, but the main shape is a 9×9 outer boundary.

dimension: About 2×2 in footprint, extending from y=0 or y=1 (foundation level) up to around y=10.
position: Attach it to one corner or side of the building, aligned with the stone_bricks walls. It should pierce through the roof (built in the next steps).
tips: Make the chimney narrow but tall for a classic “cottage” look. Keep the interior of the chimney hollow or place blocks in a vertical column—this is aesthetic, so either approach works. Optionally, widen the top or add a small ledge.
description: A functional or decorative stone_bricks chimney that helps break up the roofline and adds visual interest.

dimension: Same ~9×9 footprint, though partial walls might step inwards. 4 blocks tall: from y=4 to y=8.
position: Directly on top of the stone_bricks walls at y=4. Extend upward to y=8, forming a second story.
tips: Lay out “support beams” with spruce_planks at corners and edges. Fill the gaps between beams with birch_planks to simulate a half-timber style. Leave space for windows (either open or replaced with glass_pane if you wish to incorporate windows from the list).
description: A classic medieval/fantasy half-timber design—dark wood beams contrasted against light panels. This creates a taller, more refined second floor.

dimension: Spans roughly 9×9 horizontally, though the peaked shape narrows toward the top. he ridgeline (peak) reaches around y=11 or y=12, slightly higher than the second floor’s top (y=8).
position: Base of the roof begins just above y=8, overhanging the second-floor walls by a block or so. Apex is centered along the building’s longer axis (if the gable faces front) or whichever axis you prefer.
tips: Use stepped layers of spruce_planks to create the slope, starting from the outer edges at y=8. Gable ends can be filled with spruce_planks or left partially open for windows in the attic. Ensure the chimney extends through or just alongside the roof.
description: A steeply pitched wooden roof common in medieval or fantasy builds. The layered approach gives it a dramatic silhouette and enough interior space for an attic if desired.
